instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01949: What is 820-01949? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Arrived with liquid damage in <CHIP>U3100X</CHIP>/<CHIP>U3100T</CHIP> area and <CHIP>U3100R</CHIP>.

Stuck at 5v. Replaced U100X/<CHIP>U3100T</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100R</CHIP> along with affected resistors and caps. <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> was shorted and has been replaced as well with a new chip from Mouser. All traces affected by liquid measure good.

When trying to plug into <CHIP>U3100T</CHIP> the amp meter only comes on if inserted one way facing down. If inserted facing up the meter doesn't come on. Same goes for <CHIP>U3100R</CHIP>.

All LDO voltages are present. What should be checked next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Compare diode mode readings on CC1/2 lines between all ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
All CC1/CC2 lines now 0.725 after replacing J3300CXT/<SIGNAL>J3300_CWR</SIGNAL>

Only reaming issue is 5v and <SIGNAL>U3100_R</SIGNAL> causing the meter to cycle. All traces/resistors look good around UB260. Also replaced <SIGNAL>U3100_R</SIGNAL> with a known good <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> but no change.

What else could cause this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
You sould compare diode mode readings on all USB connector lines.
There may be a bad protection diode.
All ports must have same behavior.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
The only difference in diode mode readings I can find is 0.172 on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_R_VBUS</SIGNAL>, the only port that cycles the meter. The remaining PP20V lines are 0.130

Ive already replaced <DIODE>D3100</DIODE>  <SIGNAL>C3101_R</SIGNAL>   <SIGNAL>U3100_R</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>D3305_CWR</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
You may have bad solders on that port.
Bad components should give lower values than normal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
After reballing <SIGNAL>U3100_R</SIGNAL> all port behave the same now. 5v 0.25a.

DZ3350 is missing along with its pads. Can this alone prevent 20V??

Have a working board to compare diode mode readings and cant find any ports now that have a different diode mode reading except for  <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_R_VBUS</SIGNAL>  still 0.163  vs all other <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> only 0.130 which is the  correct value.

When this first arrived it had 20v but would not charge the battery. Not sure where to look next at this point.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Probably some bad trace, or contact, between <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> and that connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Did you ever get to the bottom of this?
